description.narrative:
Platform for Labour Action (PLA) is a registered Non-Government Organization founded in 2000 by a group of female activists in response to the absence of specific intervention to promote and protect the rights of undocumented women, youth and children inthe informal sector. It was founded and still operates on values such as professionalism, transparency, accountability, commitment, team work, respect for human rights and zero tolerance for corruption.
PLA has a theory of change and its overall is toempower communities through awareness raising on issues which affect vulnerable workers and vulnerable persons; provide free legal aid to enable access to justice; legal advocacy; policy engagement and social development sector budget monitoring, capacity development; and bridging thegap to access services including education, health, legal services among vulnerable target groups. We address the root causes of child exploitation and provide options to the vulnerable children through the rights based andlivelihood programmatic approach. These strategies result into protection of human rights and improved livelihoods of vulnerable and marginalized workers in Uganda. Our work is structured under three thematic areas namely 1) Rights Social Protection and Accountability, 2) Institutional Strengthening and3) Research Learning and Knowledge Management.
According to the Uganda National Employment policy 2011, Domestic workers are amongthe most vulnerable and marginalised workers in Uganda that need protection. Moreover, the Employment Act 2006 further exposes Domestic workers to conditions of abuse and exploitation by failing to regulate recruitment and employment of Domestic workers. According to 2017 PLA study, 93% of domestic workers are female and the majority of Domestic Workers majority 65% youths primarily from rural areas which exacerbates DWs vulnerabilities. The invisible and hidden nature of domestic work makes the DWs prone to abuses and marginalisation. Therefore an appropriate legal framework forms the basis on which domestic workers can claim their rights and begin to secure decent work. The Leaders of domestic workers (chosen by domestic workers group members to represent them) at a meeting heldin July 2018 at Kyebando Vocational Training centre unanimously agreed that the lack of a specific law on domestic work is the foundation of most of societal abuses and violations at the work place.
This project aims at promoting decent work for domestic workersin Uganda. This will be through influencing legal and policy reforms in the domestic work sector, strengthening networks of domestic workers that are able to demand for improved working conditions and increasing awareness for domestic workers and employers of domestic workers at the work place. This will result into improved quality of services rendered by domestic workers as they will carryout their work in an informed working environment.
Overall goal: To promote decent work for domestic workers in Uganda.
Objectives: 1. Strengthen networks of domestic workers influencing change in the domestic work sector. 2. Influence the enactment of the appropriate legal and policy mechanism for positive changes of their working conditions. 3. Facilitate women and female youth domestic workers' access to information

participating-org.narrative:
The organization was founded in the year 2000 by three women activists due to the absence of a voice to advocate for the rights of vulnerable and marginalised workers. The organisation has since grown in terms of geographical coverage and is currently operating in 10 districts of Uganda in three region; Eastern, Central and Northern Uganda with three offices; the headoffice in Kampala, filed offices in Lira and Iganga as well as site light offices in Amolatar, Dokolo, Kaliro. The organisation has had the opportunity to appreciate and understand the gender dynamics of the target groups through a gender mainstreaming support programme that was provided by one of her development partners the Democratic Governance Facility. This support resulted into the organisation formulating a Gender Mainstreaming strategy. The organisation has had four board chairperson since its inception. The founding members of the organisations have since left the active implementation of the day to day operations and are now at the Board of Trustees providing overall guidance to the board of directors. We have changed our office locations for the head office three times andwe are currently at plot 14 off Martyrs Lane in Ntinda Nakawa division although it is important to note we have never left Kampala. Our mission has been changed once since inception.
2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?
Our advocacy work for the Expansion of the Senior Citizens Grant in Uganda resulted into GovernmentofUganda taking a decision to roll out the Senior Citizens Grants to an additional 40 districts over the next 5 years; and greatly informed and shaped the National Social protection Policy that was approved in March 2016.
624 (313 girls and 311 boys) children from vulnerable households, at risk and exploited in domestic work and gold mining were supported to realize their right to education in vocational training institutions where they were able to acquire marketable skills that they are now using to earn decently.
93 vulnerable household heads from Kampala, Bugiri and Moroto district are now able to provide for their family especially the children to attend andstay school as wellas meet other family basic needs. This was a result from supporting income generating activities (IGAs) and income management training feasible with their abilities and the opportunities available in their areas of residence and provided start-up capital to each
PLA has generated valid and only data on the situation of Domestic workers including profiling Domestic work and its contributions to the house and economic development of the country. This data has informed and justified recommendations by the Uganda Law Reforms Commission to amend the current labour laws and regulate domestic worker.
PLA has influenced Ministry of Gender, labour and Social Development to make pronouncements that domestic workers will soon have a standardised employment contract. This is was one of the commitments made by the Honourable Minister of Gender, labour and Social Development when the 2017 study findings were presented to her.
The Government banned and halted the bilateral agreement with Saudi Arabia to send Ugandans to work as domestic workers following Civil Society Organizations including Platform for Labour Action raising concerns including maltreatment, poor working conditions and abuse of the women in Saudi Arabia to the Speaker of Parliament.
Our advocacy work on the need to operationalise the industrial court the final court in the labour related matters resulted into the re- opening andoperationalised of the court after 8 years of workers not access justice. As a result of our advocacy activities on the need to revise the minimum wage, the minimum wages advisory board was appointed and asked to carryout research on the minimum wage to advice the government. Accordingly PLA#s advocacy activitiesin the social protection and pension sector led to the currentand ongoing liberalisation reforms in the pensions sector.
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE
The Vision: A society where democratic values and social justice are respected and observed in the world of work
Mission Statement: Promoting and protecting the rights of vulnerable and marginalized workers through empowerment of communities and individuals, action oriented research, policy dialogue, and legal aid in Uganda
Mission:What is the current purpose of the organisation?Promoting and protecting the rights of vulnerable and marginalized workers responding to their needs and handling poor persons within the informal economy and low-income earners through provision of free legal aid services and empowering communities and individuals.
Institutional objectives:What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?To empower communities through awareness raising on issues which affect vulnerable workers; provide free legal aid to enable access to justice; legal advocacy; policy engagement and social development sector budget monitoring, capacity development; and bridging the gap to access services including education, health, legal services among vulnerable target groups. These strategies will result into protection of human rights and improved livelihoods of vulnerable and marginalized workers in Uganda.
Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?
Our work is structured underthreethematic areas namely 1) Rights Social Protection and Accountability, Institutional Strengthening and Research Learning andKnowledge Management. The organisation currently operates in 10 districts of Uganda from three regions; central, Eastern and Northern regions. In central regionthe districtsinclude; Kampala, Mukono and Wakiso; Northern Uganda-Lira, Dokolo and Amolatar in the Eastern Region- Iganga, Kaliro, Bugiri, Busia, Tororo and Bugweri. Our target group include children in exploitative forms of work and those at risk of exploitation, low income earners earning USD 150 andbelow, Youth and Women.
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment inwhich the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the positionof the organisation?
Overall, Uganda has registered an increase in incomepoverty in the last three years from 19.7% in 2013 to 27% in 2017 (UBOS 2016/17 Uganda National Household Survey (UNHS)) with the eastern region experiencing thehighest incidences of poverty at 42%, followedbythe northernregionat39% . With the increase in the income poverty levels, poor vulnerable and marginalised persons are unable to access justice when faced with legal problems due to the costs involved compounded by the limited ability to articulate legal provisions, technical processes and procedures (JLOS Fourth Strategic Development Plan 2017-2020). Currently, the Ugandan economy can only absorb about 15% ofthe young people completing post-primary education and released onto the job market leaving the majority unemployed. The employment challenge has resulted into 70% (Uganda Labour Market Profile 2016) of the labour force absorbed in the informal sector which remains insufficiently supported, not regulated and characterised with noncompliance with the labour and employment standards leading to multiple rights violations and abuses of workers in this sector (The Uganda National Employment Policy 2011).The unemployment challenge has further led to increased labour migration especially among the youths amidst limited access to information on safe migration options, insufficient job orientation, weak legal and policy frame works, as well as the minimal and unpublicised government protection measures in the countries of destination amongst the migrants.PLA is the only legal aid service provider that directly targets informal economy and low income earnersand with 14 years of experience in handling vulnerable and marginalized workers# issues, simplification and translation of labour related laws, informing legislative and policy reforms in the social protection and pensions sector.
